question_text: You need to summarize a PDF containing the company's financial strategy for next year. To save time, you upload it to a public AI chatbot. Is this safe?
options: Yes, if I delete the file afterwards
No, public AI models may train on your data
Yes, if the AI promises privacy
explanation_feedback: Never upload internal documents to public AI tools. Anything you type can become part of the AI's public database and leak to competitors. Use only enterprise-approved tools.

question_text: You are writing a client contract and use AI to generate a clause. It looks perfect. What is your next step?
options: Send it to the client immediately
explanation_feedback: AI is not a lawyer. It can hallucinate laws or create unenforceable clauses. Always have a qualified human expert review legal output.

question_text: A colleague suggests using a free online AI tool to 'optimize' the source code of your proprietary software. They say it's fine because they removed the comments.
options: Go ahead, code logic isn't confidential
Refuse, the code structure itself is IP
Do it, but change variable names first
explanation_feedback: Your code logic is Intellectual Property. Uploading it to a third-party AI gives them a license to view and potentially use your IP. This is a major data leak.

question_text: You find a new AI meeting assistant that records and transcribes Zoom calls automatically. It requires 'Read/Write' access to your Calendar.
options: Use it only for internal meetings
explanation_feedback: This is 'Shadow IT'. Granting third-party apps access to corporate calendars can expose confidential meeting details and attendee lists. Always vet tools through IT.

question_text: An AI tool generates a report citing a specific regulation 'EU-2024-Alpha'. You've never heard of it.
options: Trust the AI, it has access to more data
Google the regulation to verify it exists
Ask the AI for the source link
explanation_feedback: AI frequently 'hallucinates' facts, including fake court cases and regulations. Always verify specific citations independently.

question_text: You want to use ChatGPT to draft a sensitive email to a client. How should you prompt it?
options: Paste the client's email chain for context
Describe the situation generically without names or data
Use the client's first name only
explanation_feedback: Sanitize your inputs. Remove all PII (Personally Identifiable Information) and specific data points before asking public AI for assistance.

question_text: You receive a LinkedIn connection request from a recruiter at a competitor. They ask for your work email to send a 'confidential job description'.
explanation_feedback: While it could be real, fake recruiters are a common way to map corporate directories. If you are interested, use a personal email, never your work address.

question_text: A 'Vendor' emails an updated invoice with new bank details. The email comes from 'vendor-billing@gmail.com'.
options: Reply asking for a signed letter
Call the vendor's known contact number
explanation_feedback: Business Email Compromise (BEC) is huge. Legitimate businesses rarely use @gmail.com for billing. Always verify payment changes via a second channel (phone).

question_text: Your boss sends a voice note on WhatsApp: 'I'm locked out, please text me the 2FA code sent to your phone.'
explanation_feedback: Voice cloning is used to bypass security. A boss should never need YOUR 2FA code. Call them immediately to confirm the hack.

question_text: You are training an internal AI model for HR. Is it okay to use historical hiring data that includes age and gender?
explanation_feedback: Using protected characteristics (age, gender, race) can lead to algorithmic bias and discrimination lawsuits. Data must be carefully curated for fairness.

question_text: A client asks if your company uses AI to process their data. You use a little bit for spell-checking.
explanation_feedback: Transparency is a legal requirement under regulations like GDPR. You must disclose if and how AI interacts with client data.

question_text: You take a photo of your desk to show off your setup on LinkedIn. Your monitor is visible.
options: Post it, the text is too small to read
explanation_feedback: High-res cameras and AI upscaling can make even tiny text readable. 'Desk selfies' are a common source of data leaks. Blur screens or turn them off.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: IT sends an email: 'Mandatory Security Update. Click here to install.' The link goes to 'company-it-support.net'.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! 'company-it-support.net' is likely a phishing site. Corporate updates are usually pushed automatically or hosted on internal domains. Verify before clicking.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: You discover a colleague is using a personal ChatGPT account to analyze customer support logs.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! This is a GDPR violation. Customer data is being sent to a third party without consent. It puts the company at massive legal risk and must be reported.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: A 'Journalist' calls asking for a comment on a rumor about your company's finances. They sound friendly.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! Social engineers pose as journalists to extract info. Only authorized spokespeople should speak to the press. 'Off the record' is not a guarantee.

question_text: You see a video of a CEO announcing a massive stock sell-off. The stock price drops. Later, it's proven fake.
options: Check the company's official Investor Relations page
explanation_feedback: Deepfakes are used for market manipulation. Never trade on a single video source. Verify with official regulatory filings or company press releases.

question_text: An image shows a politician being arrested. The hands of the police officers look blurry and have 6 fingers.
explanation_feedback: AI struggles with hands and text. Extra fingers or 'melted' hands are a hallmark of AI generation. Always look at the details.

question_text: A news article has a sensational headline but no author name and the website is 'Daily-News-247.xyz'.
explanation_feedback: Fake news sites often have anonymous authors and generic domains. Check the 'About Us' section; if it's missing or vague, the site is likely a content farm.

question_text: You see a post that makes you incredibly angry immediately. What is the likely goal of the post?
options: To bypass your critical thinking via emotion
explanation_feedback: Rage-bait is designed to trigger an emotional response so you share without thinking. If a post makes you furious, pause and verify.

question_text: A 'Doctor' on TikTok recommends a miracle cure that 'Big Pharma' is hiding. They have 1M followers.
explanation_feedback: Followers can be bought. A white coat is a costume. Always verify medical advice against consensus from reputable health organizations.

question_text: What is a 'Bot Farm'?
options: A place where robots grow food
A network of fake accounts used to amplify specific narratives
explanation_feedback: Bot farms use thousands of automated accounts to like/share posts, making fringe opinions look like popular majority views (Astroturfing).

question_text: You want to verify an image. What tool can you use?
explanation_feedback: Reverse Image Search helps you find the original source of an image. You might find the 'war zone' photo is actually from a movie set 5 years ago.

question_text: A quote attributed to a famous historical figure supports a modern political view perfectly.
options: Search for the quote on a fact-checking site
explanation_feedback: Fake quotes are rampant. If a historical figure sounds like a modern pundit, it's likely fake. Sites like Snopes or Quote Investigator can verify.

question_text: A video shows a politician slurring their words. It could be:
explanation_feedback: Before assuming, check for 'Cheapfakes'â€”videos that are simply slowed down to make someone sound impaired. Compare with other footage from the event.

question_text: You realize a story you shared yesterday is false. What should you do?
options: Delete it and pretend it never happened
Delete it and post a correction
Leave it up, it got likes
explanation_feedback: Integrity matters. Deleting prevents further spread, but posting a correction informs those who already saw it. Be part of the solution.

question_text: Why is 'Lateral Reading' better than reading vertically (staying on the page)?
options: It involves opening new tabs to verify the site's reputation elsewhere
explanation_feedback: Don't trust the 'About' page of a suspicious site. Open new tabs and search for what OTHER reputable sources say about that site.

question_text: A friend posts a conspiracy theory. How do you engage?
options: Send a private message with a fact-check link
explanation_feedback: Public shaming often digs people deeper into their beliefs. A private, empathetic message with a reliable source is more effective.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: A viral audio clip leaks of a candidate admitting to a crime. The audio quality is perfect, no background noise.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! Real secret recordings are rarely studio-quality. Perfect audio with no background noise is a strong indicator of AI generation.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: You are asked to donate to a 'Disaster Relief Fund' immediately after a tragedy. The site accepts only Crypto.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! Scammers exploit tragedies. Legitimate charities accept credit cards/checks. Crypto-only donations for relief funds are almost always scams.

question_text: BOSS LEVEL: A website looks exactly like 'BBC News' but the URL is 'bbc-news-live.com'.
explanation_feedback: CRITICAL HIT! This is Typosquatting/Spoofing. Scammers clone legitimate news sites to push fake narratives. Always check the URL carefully.
